hint: It might be helpful to Google™ the error.
description:
After opening the robot's front panel and looking inside, you discover a small red button behind a tangle of wires. Pressing the button lights up the robot's primary screen. It glows black and quickly flashes blue. A line of small text types out: 

ERROR: 0x00000023

The text refreshes and displays the prompt: 

FILE SYSTEM RECOVERY INITIATED...
FILE SYSTEM COULD NOT BE IDENTIFIED...
PLEASE ENTER FILE SYSTEM FORMAT:
name: Failure to Boot

hint: There are MD5 implementations for every major programming language. If you don't know what a salt is, don't worry, it's just a string appended to the password.
description: I'm bad
name: Try Them All!

hint: You may want to check out the video on substitution ciphers.
description: I'm bad.
name: Read the Manual

hint: Learning to use a command-line interface can be very empowering!.
description: After plugging the robot into the computer, the robot asks for the name of a file containing the string SECRET AUTH CODE. You can find it using the command-line interface in /problems/grep.tar or by downloading all of the files.
name: Grep is Your Friend

hint: It looks like an animated GIF.
description: The map of the spaceport is hard to parse, but you're pretty sure there is some hidden information, somewhere...
name: Spaceport Map

hint: Have a look at this for some good truth tables for bitops
description:
You see the doors to the loading bay of the hangar, but they are locked. However, you are able to extract the password verification program from the control panel... Can you find the password to gain access to the loading bay?

Available in Python or Java
name: Bitwise

hint: You're probably going to want to use a decompiler for this, such as jd-gui
description: I'm bad.
name: Byte Code

hint: Most filesystems have a way to hide files from being listed.  How can you make ls ignore it?
description:
You've gotten a partial dump of the disk from the hangar's machine, and you're pretty sure the pilot's password is cleverly hidden somewhere within it...

The disk image can be found on the shell machines at /problems/pilot_logic.img and the contents of the image are available in /problems/pilot_logic/
name: Pilot Logic

description:
Wouldn't it be cool to be able to have one of these patrol drones to do your bidding?! Figure out the correct sequence of C functions from the following control flow graphs and you should be well on your way.

Submit the correct order of functions.
name: CFG to C

hint: What is a file? What is XML?
description: I'm bad.
name: XMLOL

hint: Look very closely at the url and think about it a little
description: There's bound to be a key on the spaceport's hidden website
name: GETKey

hint: It may help to learn a bit about network communication on the Internet and Wireshark.
description:
You notice that the indicator light near the robot’s antenna begins to blink. Perhaps the robot is connecting to a network? Using a wireless card and the network protocol analyzer Wireshark, you are able to create a PCAP file containing the packets sent over the network.

You suspect that the robot is communicating with the crashed ship. Your goal is to find the location of the ship by inspecting the network traffic.

You can perform the analysis online on Cloudshark or you can download the PCAP file.
name: First Contact

description:
The spaceport technician waves to you and you approach him. He tells you that he has noticed you walking around suspiciously. He adds that he knows the door code and is willing to give it to you for answering a small trivia question.

For what kind of car was the first unlocked iPhone traded?
name: Technician Challenge

hint: You know what's yummy? Cookies are yummy.
description:
You want to find out the docking bay numbers for space ships that are ready to launch. Luckily for you, the website for the docking bay ship status page doesn't seem so secure....

Enter the docking bay for any of the ships that are awaiting launch.
name: Yummy

hint: You should look at the first two bytes of the docx file, and then think about them a little bit...
description: While flying through the outskirts of the Ripley system, you notice a distress signal from one of the outer moons. It appears a ship has crash-landed near a 16-sided pyramid. The lone survivor, a docx file, tells you that a malicious programmer has embedded an egg in his chest and he's afraid that it's going to hatch. He offers his assistance if you can help find the egg.
name: In Hex, No One Can Hear You Complain

hint: What are some famous encodings that only use two values?
description: We recorded the following communication between two robots. Find out what evil things they are plotting, and recover their secret key!
name: Robomunication

hint: As the name of the problem might suggest, you should look into file carving
description: While exploring an alien tomb, you find an ancient jpg of an ancient can of SPAM. It seems valueless, but the guardbots really want it back, so perhaps there's something more here than meets the eye. Maybe it's cursed, or hexed, if you will?
name: Spamcarver

hint: gdb can load and read core files
description: In a ruined city on a forgotten world, you find a broken cogitator controlling access to the Vault. You have blueprints for the machine, and a stickynote attached to the monitor with the encrypted input. The machine seems to have crashed while decrypting, and generated a core dump, too. Maybe if you can get the encryption keys out of the core dump, you can decrypt the ciphertext and get the vault open... Files available for download here on on the shell machine in /problems/core_decrypt.tar
name: Core Decryption

hint: You may find this useful.
description: While refueling at a gas giant, you are hailed by a race of cuttlefish-people who dwell within it. Their transmission is entirely visual; you suspect that they may be communicating through the color values.
name: Chromatophoria

hint: Look for packets going to and from a search engine, and the key is the name of the author of the thing they're looking for
description:
As you're bumming around the Kuiper Belt, you catch an incoming transmission from a distant source. They seem to be scanning the area, looking for something... Maybe you should try to find it first.

This trace file is also available in cloudshark here
name: Second Contact

hint: This list might be of interest to you
description: Near the Sun, you find a malfunctioning warp beacon which is broadcasting a distress signal in a navigational channel. It looks like it's been damaged by solar radiation, and some of its data have been corrupted. If you can recover it, perhaps it will point at you to something interesting.
name: NAVSAT

hint: What have you used to find hidden files in easier forensics problems?
description:
Sure are a lot of stars out there... but there's a lot of empty space for things to hide in, too.

The disk image can be found on the shell machines at /problems/dark_star.img and the contents of the image are available in /problems/dark_star/
name: Dark Star

description:
An unlocked terminal is displaying the following:

Encryption complete, ENC(???,T0pS3cre7key) = Bot kmws mikferuigmzf rmfrxrwqe abs perudsf! Nvm kda ut ab8bv_w4ue0_ab8v_DDU
You poke around and find this interesting file.
name: Trivial

description:
Someone or something stuck a random flyer on your space ship that reads:

cslcehesehft ohrumvc zmvm scmk ht ptohmte ehbmc mxmt eufsju eumq pvm dshem mpchgq lvfymt zheu nsce p rmtohg ptk rprmv, fv bfvm vmomtegq lq ofbbft ofbrsemvhwmk effgc. qfsv ymq hc: zumt_kf_zm_jme_ef_eum_upvk_cesii
name: Classic

hint: They still teach you to solve systems of equations in math classes, right?
description: We found a small scout ship which could aid in your mission, but it is a RoboCorpIntergalactic product, and requires a serial number before you can use it. This serial verifier looks a lot like the one our robot used, but now the serial number needs to be 20 digits. Can you take a look and find a valid serial number?
name: Harder Serial

hint: Have a look at a simple introduction to python's eval here
description: A wise master wishes to teach you an ancient art: Python Eval 1.
name: Python Eval 1

hint: What expression can you make the program eval that will tell you the key?
description: It is recommended that you complete Python Eval 1 before trying Python Eval 2.
name: Python Eval 2

description: Give Python Eval 1 and 2 a shot before moving on to Python Eval 3.
name: Python Eval 3

description: Solving the previous Python Eval probelms will help you prepare for Python Eval 4
name: Python Eval 4

description: A true challenge awaits you at python.picoctf.com:6365. Source.
name: Python Eval 5

hint: You should consider using a java decompiler, such as jd-gui
description: elif avaJ
name: avaJ

hint: Read the code very carefully, and figure out what each function call does
description:
If you can guess the admin's password you can get a key

Problem - Source
name: Pretty Hard Programming

hint: Sorry, no hint for this problem :(
description: Figure out the key from this game
name: Evergreen

hint: This page should tell you enough to figure the formulae out on this one. Then it's just math with very large numbers.
description: Math is cool! Use the RSA algorithm to decode the secret message, c, p, q, and e are parameters for the RSA algorithm. Problem
name: RSA

hint: You should read up on format string vulnerabilities. Also feel free to ask us for help!
description:
A simple introduction to the format string family of vulnerabilities. These let you read and write memory in fantastic ways.

Problem can be found in

/problems/format_1_d407f39cdf584627
on the shell machine, binary downloadable here source here.
name: Format 1

hint: The trick here is to overwrite one of the entries in the global offset table
description:
A simple introduction to the format string family of vulnerabilities. These let you read and write memory in fantastic ways.

Problem can be found in

/problems/format_2_358e7afd8b3804d8
on the shell machine, binary downloadable here source here.
name: Format 2

description:
ROP is a classic technique for getting around address randomization and non-executable memory. This sequence will teach you the basics.

Problem available on the shell machine in /problems/ROP_1_fa6168f4d8eba0eb , downloadable here with source here.

If you solve the problem you will be able to read the key file by running

cat /problems/ROP_1_fa6168f4d8eba0eb/key
on the PicoCTF shell machine
name: ROP 1

hint: objdump -t can get you the address in memory of the string /bin/bash...  and then you need to figure out how to pass it as an argument to a call to system somehow
description:
ROP is a classic technique for getting around address randomization and non-executable memory. This sequence will teach you the basics.

Problem available on the shell machine in /problems/ROP_2_20f65dd0bcbe267d , downloadable here with source here.

If you solve the problem you will be able to read the key file by running

cat /problems/ROP_2_20f65dd0bcbe267d/key
on the PicoCTF shell machine
name: ROP 2

hint: You're going to need to use gdb and search through libc for the address of system, exec, or a similar syscall wrapper.
description:
ROP is a classic technique for getting around address randomization and non-executable memory. This sequence will teach you the basics.

Problem available on the shell machine in /problems/ROP_3_7f3312fe43c46d26 , downloadable here with source here.

If you solve the problem you will be able to read the key file by running

cat /problems/ROP_3_7f3312fe43c46d26/key
on the PicoCTF shell machine
name: ROP 3

hint: oops, we messed up and use strcpy instead of strcat - but it's still solvable!
description: Problem has been updated April 28th at midnight ESTAnother ROP problem, this time a bit harder than before. Available on the shell machine in /problems/ROP_4_887f7f28b1f64d7e .
name: ROP 4

hint: In general, the compiler will put things on the stack in the order they appear in the code.  Also google 'endianness'
description:
Stack overflows are the most basic binary exploitation technique, but they take a lot of skill to master. If you already know some C, these problems can help acquaint you with stacks and binary exploitation in general.

Problem available on the shell machine in /problems/stack_overflow_1_3948d17028101c40 , downloadable here with source here.

If you solve the problem you will be able to read the key file by running

cat /problems/stack_overflow_1_3948d17028101c40/key
on the PicoCTF shell machine.
name: Overflow 1

hint: A function's arguments live on top of its stack frame, above its saved ebp and return address.  Make sure not to clobber those, though...
description:
Stack overflows are the most basic binary exploitation technique, but they take a lot of skill to master. If you already know some C, these problems can help acquaint you with stacks and binary exploitation in general.

Problem available on the shell machine in /problems/stack_overflow_2_44e63640e033ff2b , downloadable here with source here.

If you solve the problem you will be able to read the key file by running

cat /problems/stack_overflow_2_44e63640e033ff2b/key
on the PicoCTF shell machine.
name: Overflow 2

hint: objdump -d is a handy tool for this sort of thing.
description:
Stack overflows are the most basic binary exploitation technique, but they take a lot of skill to master. If you already know some C, these problems can help acquaint you with stacks and binary exploitation in general.

Problem available on the shell machine in /problems/stack_overflow_3_28d8a442fb232c0c , downloadable here with source here.

If you solve the problem you will be able to read the key file by running

cat /problems/stack_overflow_3_28d8a442fb232c0c/key
on the PicoCTF shell machine.
name: Overflow 3

hint: Gonna need some shellcode. Luckily some is provided for you in the directory on the shell machine.
description:
Stack overflows are the most basic binary exploitation technique, but they take a lot of skill to master. If you already know some C, these problems can help acquaint you with stacks and binary exploitation in general.

Problem available on the shell machine in /problems/stack_overflow_4_4834efeff17abdfb , downloadable here with source here.

If you solve the problem you will be able to read the key file by running

cat /problems/stack_overflow_4_4834efeff17abdfb/key
on the PicoCTF shell machine.

hint: Now you don't have source, and you aren't allowed to execute code on the stack.  Keep calm and objdump -d
description:
Stack overflows are the most basic binary exploitation technique, but they take a lot of skill to master. If you already know some C, these problems can help acquaint you with stacks and binary exploitation in general.

Problem available on the shell machine in /problems/stack_overflow_5_0353c1a83cb2fa0d , downloadable here. Source is not available for this problem.

If you solve the problem you will be able to read the key file by running

cat /problems/stack_overflow_5_0353c1a83cb2fa0d/key
on the PicoCTF shell machine.
name: Overflow 5

hint: ls -b will help you get past the first hurdle.  Good luck and godspeed.
description:
Near the galactic core, you find a beacon indicating that an ancient civilization hid one of their worlds within a nearby black hole. Is this what passes for intergalactic humor, or is there actually something in there?

The disk image can be found on the shell machines at /problems/blackhole.img and the contents of the image are available in /problems/blackhole/
name: Black Hole

hint: Connect to the service using 'nc vuln.picoctf.com 4567'. You may find this reference on padding oracle attacks helpful
description: We found this service running on vuln.picoctf.com. Unfortunately the sensitive information such as the encryption keys, IV, and flag have all been deleted. Our cryptographic spies tell us it is still insecure, but we aren't sure how to send it commands. Do you think you can figure it out?
name: Broken CBC

hint: You probably want to reverse this dynamically, with a tool like gdb
description:
This binary reversing challenge seems deceptively simple. Can you figure out the key that it accepts?

Binary available on the shell machine in /problems/mildly_evil/ and available for download here
name: Mildly Evil

hint: The SQL query being performed is something a lot like SELECT username,hash FROM pwtable WHERE username= your_input
description: Use the Loading Bay Control System to get the admin key! Problem
name: Injection

hint: First rule of web hacking: always read the page source
description: Luckily the ship has a web-based authentication system! Hmm…even though you don't know the password, I bet you can still get in!
name: Client-Side is the Best Side

hint: What's a defining pattern in a syn flood attack?
description:
It appears a SYN-flood style DDoS has been carried out on this system. Send us a list of the IP addresses of the attackers (in any order, separated by spaces), so we can track them down and stop them.

Pcap available to download here, or available to analyse online at CloudShark
name: DDoS Detection

description: We found a simple web page that seems to want us to authenticate, but we can't figure out how... can you?
name: PHP2

hint: Look at the PHP md5 function. What does it do when the second argument is True, and how can you make use of that?
description: It looks like this site uses MD5 to hash passwords, but I don't think they're doing it quite right...
name: PHP3

hint: They are still vulnerable to SQL injection. What can you do to make your code bypass all the checks?
description:
It looks like our web administrators updated their MD5 code after the PHP3 fiasco. However, I still don't think they fixed all the bugs on this site.

Can you show them what they did wrong by logging in again?
name: PHP4

hint: Download IDA and stare at it for a few hours. It's a very difficult problem, and there aren't really any shortcuts... good luck
description:
This robot looks... particularly evil. It seems like it only accepts one key, and if you find it, the robot will do your bidding. Can you find the valid key, and gain control over the robot?

Download the binary here or look on the shell machine in /problems/moreevil/
name: moreevil

hint: It turns out Java can be decompiled...
description:
This is a compiled Java class file. It looks like it will accept a password, but only one. Can you find the password and control the planet?

Download the class file here or look on the shell machine in /problems/hotcoffee/
name: hotcoffee

hint: Connect from the shell with 'nc vuln.picoctf.com 6666'. Read up on RSA and try to figure out why this might be bad... Good luck!
description:
This RSA service seems to be broken. They encrypt the flag and send it to you each time... but they throw out the private key and you never get to see it. Any ideas on how to recover the flag?

Running on vuln.picoctf.com
name: Broken RSA
